description: Lenart Kova secretly reroutes the city's analog network, allowing returnees and affected citizens to broadcast their experiences and evidence of wrongful BCI detainment across the city. The broadcast rapidly gains public attention and triggers citywide debate.

Public pressure mounts as citizens rally in major squares, demanding accountability and an independent review of the BCI system. The Council, facing unrest and exposure of abuses, announces the launch of a temporary Citizen Tribunal and promises transparency.

The Citizen Tribunal broadcasts testimonies of returnees and wrongfully flagged citizens citywide. Evidence of BCI abuse, data errors, and misuse by officials leads to several high-profile demotions during live hearings.

Citing risks to public order, the Directorate faction suspends the Tribunal and imposes a media blackout. Access to analog broadcast channels is restricted, and Council control tightens amid backlash from the public.
Disillusioned citizens mark the brief era of transparency with gatherings, songs, and chalk messages, turning the Citizen Tribunal into a symbol of fleeting openness and failed reform.
